ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about the culture of various Spanish-speaking countries and the socioeconomic struggles which they face. I got much better at speaking in Spanish throughout the class and became much more comfortable challenging myself with new vocabulary and grammar structures.

I learned about how values are expressed through art and how different cultures portray their beliefs. We learned about spanish speaking countries in different parts of the world and read books by latino/a authors.
Speaking in spanish, intricacies of Latinx cultures, grammar

I developed vocabulary to talk about art/social problems in Spanish, useful grammatical structures for reflections about Latinx culture, and my ability to engage in discussions in Spanish about Hispanic culture.
Subjunctive, transition words, how to discuss opinions, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really loved the discussion-based structure of the class, I thought it was really helpful for language development and speaking skill. I felt like I was learning applicable skills and about very relevant topics. The collaborative nature of the class made it really enjoyable as well. The only thing is I wish there was a brief time allocated, maybe a homework assignment or one day, to review grammar structure as we move through the units.
I loved getting to explore latino/a culture through different sources (movies, books, art, etc).
More grammar lessons and detailed explanations

Strengths: lots of different mediums to engage students (art, music, literature, etc.), many opportunities to practice new vocabulary and grammatical structures in conversation to improve speaking ability, great classroom environment
Kind of weakness: discussions for units could feel repetitive at times since some units lasted for a few weeks

Strengths: Low-stress course that actually valued conversing and discussions to facilitate language learning
Weaknesses: Since it meets everyday, there are daily homework assignments and projects/writing assignments at times which drags on after awhile.
Strengths included the workload and ability to engage, as well as the asynchronous day!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, and I already have. This was the best Spanish class Ive ever taken, both in terms of enjoyment and in learning.

Yes, I would 100% recommend this course. Although it focuses more on culture and stories than grammar and vocabulary you learn how to be a better spanish student and speaker and the class is a lot of fun.

Yes, it is a great way to interact with the language in ways you might not expect. You learn to have real conversations about relevant topics and not just food or activities or basic sentence structures as you might in high school.
Yes, if you need a language credit or you want a basic intro to various aspects of Latinx culture
